org.tair.sql.expression
Interface IExpression

All Known Subinterfaces:
IAliasedExpression, IMultipleParameterExpression, IScalarExpression<T>, ISelectExpression<T>, ISingleParameterExpression<P>, ISubqueryExpression
All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractMultipleParameterExpression, AbstractSingleParameterExpression, AliasedExpression, BigDecimalExpression, BigDecimalParameterExpression, BigDecimalSubqueryExpression, BigIntegerExpression, BigIntegerParameterExpression, BigIntegerSubqueryExpression, BooleanExpression, BooleanParameterExpression, BooleanSubqueryExpression, Expression, IntegerExpression, IntegerParameterExpression, IntegerSubqueryExpression, ParameterizedSubqueryExpression, ScalarSubqueryExpression, StringExpression, StringParameterExpression, StringSubqueryExpression, SubqueryExpression, TimestampExpression, TimestampParameterExpression, TimestampSubqueryExpression
public interface IExpression

An interface defining the operations available for any SQL expression

A SQL value expression represented as a string that you can append to a StringBuilder while constructing a SQL statement. The expression is intended to be one of these types:

  • a column reference
  • a function call
  • an arithmetic expression
  • a subquery (table, row, or scalar)

Other possibilities are there, but the expression has no internal structure other than lexical substitution variables. In particular, value expressions that are boolean expressions are handled separately as "predicates", while a simple boolean expression returning (for example) a column value of true or false is an expression, not a predicate. This division allows for relatively complex predicates but handles every other kind of expression as an unstructured string.

The lexical variable substitution interface allows the client to substitute a string value into the internal expression string, which may have embedded variable values in the format ${var}. The concrete expression implementation should represent the expression string with the variable and code a method for resolving the variable into the setVariable method. If the variable does not exist in the expression, the setVariable method should throw an exception.

Author:
Robert J. Muller

Method Detail

getSql

void getSql(java.lang.StringBuilder builder)
Append the SQL expression into the string builder.

Parameters:
builder - the string builder into which to append the elements of the SQL expression; the builder may already contain the preceding part of the SQL statement

getVariable

java.lang.String getVariable(java.lang.String variable)
                             throws NoSuchLexicalVariableException
Get the current value of a lexical variable; if the variable does not exist in the lexical variable map, returns null

Parameters:
variable - the name of the variable for which to get the value
Returns:
the value of the variable specified
Throws:
NoSuchLexicalVariableException - when the variable does not exist in the map of variables

setVariable

void setVariable(java.lang.String variable,
                 java.lang.String value)
                 throws NoSuchLexicalVariableException
Set the value of a lexical variable; if the variable does not exist, throws a runtime exception.

Parameters:
variable - the name of the lexical variable
value - the value to assign to the lexical variable and to substitute for it in the SQL string generated by the getSQL method
Throws:
NoSuchLexicalVariableException - when the variable does not exist in the map of variables
